alert.note: Alert for Orange; Seminole; Volusia (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 29 at 5:51AM EDT until September 29 at 8:15AM EDT by NWS Melbourne
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY FOR SANFORD, LAKE MARY, HEATHROW... ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 815 AM EDT THIS MORNING FOR CENTRAL ORANGE, SEMINOLE AND SOUTH CENTRAL VOLUSIA COUNTIES... At 551 AM EDT, Local law enforcement reported water rescues at SR-46 at I-4. Between 9 and 11 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring. This is a FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY for Sanford, Lake Mary, Heathrow. This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Heavy rain producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Law enforcement reported. IMPACT...This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! Life threatening flash flooding of low water crossings, small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Orlando, Deltona, Sanford, Altamonte Springs, Oviedo, Winter Springs, Winter Park, DeLand, Casselberry, New Smyrna Beach, Maitland, Lake Mary, Longwood, Orange City, Lake Helen, Lake Jessup, DeBary, Geneva, Goldenrod and University Of Central Florida. This includes the following streams and drainages... Gee Creek, Little Econlockhatchee River, Saint Johns River, Econlockhatchee River, Wekiva River and Cow Creek. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CATASTROPHIC
info.instruction: Move to higher ground now! This is an extremely dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
